news_header: Cabinet ministers express concerns over proposed departmental cuts and a potential £40bn funding gap ahead of the upcoming Budget.
President Joe Biden embarks on a farewell tour, receiving the Federal Cross of Merit in Germany, marking his significant role in US-Germany relations.

J.D. Vance, Trump's vice presidential candidate, has been evasive about the 2020 election results but recently stated he wouldn't use the words 'Trump lost' despite acknowledging issues in the election.
Nokia reports a decline in net sales and operating profits for Q3, but maintains its 2024 outlook.
The US conducted precision strikes against Houthi-controlled weapons storage in Yemen to counter attacks on shipping in the Red Sea.
Nordea's operating profit for Q3 was EUR 1.6 billion, a 5% decrease year-on-year.
United Utilities illegally dumped over 140 million litres of raw sewage into Windermere, failing to report most incidents, prompting environmental concerns and investigations.
The EU summit focuses on immigration policies, particularly Finland's new laws and Poland's asylum approach amid concerns over asylum seekers from Belarus and Russia.
Russian attacks in Idlib, Syria result in casualties.
North Korea has amended its constitution to label South Korea as a 'hostile state,' marking a significant shift in its official stance.
Liam Payne, former One Direction star, died at 31 in Argentina after falling from a hotel balcony.
A Georgia judge has blocked seven election rules favored by Trump, citing interference with the voting process.
European manufacturers showcased new car models at the Paris Motor Show while grappling with the challenges posed by cheap Chinese electric vehicles.
Biden meets European leaders in Berlin to discuss support for Ukraine.
Singer Liam Payne has died at 31, and Dame Maggie Smith has also passed away at 89. The BBC reflects on their careers and other notable events in entertainment.
President Alexander Stubbin and Crown Prince Haakon of Norway conclude their visit in Bergen.
Kamala Harris discusses immigration, economics, and foreign policy in her first interview with Fox News.
Former One Direction singer Liam Payne was found dead after falling from a hotel balcony in Buenos Aires.

EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen discusses the potential of adopting Italy's offshore migrant processing policy in Albania, as the EU prepares for a summit on migration and proposes new deportation legislation.
The text discusses how WhatsApp operates as a free messaging platform, its revenue model, and compares it to other messaging apps.
NATO defence ministers meet in Brussels with Ukrainian President Zelensky presenting his victory plan.
Liam Payne, a former member of One Direction, tragically died at 31 after falling from a hotel balcony in Buenos Aires.

Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman attended the first EU-GCC summit in Brussels, marking a significant diplomatic return despite past controversies. The summit focused on geopolitical issues, including the conflicts in Ukraine and the Middle East, energy cooperation, and trade discussions.
Italy has banned surrogacy abroad, extending its existing ban and imposing severe penalties, which critics argue targets LGBT couples.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky presents a 'victory plan' to end the war with Russia, emphasizing military strength and NATO membership.
Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau accuses India of involvement in the murder of a Sikh separatist leader, escalating diplomatic tensions between the two countries.
The US has pressured Israel to improve humanitarian access in Gaza, threatening military aid cuts if changes aren't made within 30 days.
Intensified fighting in Sudan between the Sudanese Armed Forces and the Rapid Support Forces has resulted in significant civilian casualties and a worsening humanitarian crisis.
Yvonne Aki-Sawyerr, mayor of Freetown, Sierra Leone, has transformed the city through sustainable initiatives and was awarded the 2024 German Africa Prize for her efforts.
A tragic incident at a Crimean Safari Park resulted in the death of an employee after being attacked by lions.
The text describes the aftermath of Israeli air strikes in Gaza City, highlighting the devastation, loss of life, and humanitarian crisis faced by the survivors.
Niger's military government is renaming streets and monuments to sever ties with France, its former colonial power, amidst deteriorating relations following a coup.
The UN criticizes Israel for air strikes in Lebanon that killed the mayor and others, raising concerns about violations of international humanitarian law.
A fuel tanker explosion in northern Nigeria resulted in at least 147 fatalities and numerous injuries as people rushed to collect leaking petrol.
Ukrainian journalist Viktoria Roshchyna died in Russian custody after reporting on the war in Ukraine, raising concerns about the treatment of journalists.
Taffel is reducing the packaging size of its largest scissors from 325 grams to 250-270 grams based on consumer demand for smaller sizes.
Kamala Harris criticizes Donald Trump's recent rhetoric, labeling it dangerous and divisive as he refers to political opponents as 'internal enemies' and suggests military action against dissenters.
Researchers have discovered how human skin is created from stem cells, which could lead to advancements in slowing aging and producing artificial skin.
A fuel tanker explosion in Nigeria resulted in at least 140 deaths and numerous injuries.
UK inflation unexpectedly fell to 1.7% in September, the lowest in three-and-a-half years, driven by lower airfares and petrol prices, potentially leading to interest rate cuts.
The U.S. has warned Israel to improve humanitarian aid delivery to Gaza within 30 days or face consequences, emphasizing the need for increased access and support amidst worsening conditions.
Easter Island faces a severe plastic waste problem, accumulating 50 times more plastic than Chile despite its small size.

Support for military juntas in Mali, Burkina Faso, and Niger is declining due to unmet promises and harsh tactics by Russian mercenaries, leading to protests against Russian influence and increasing repression of dissent.

A Spanish documentary claims Christopher Columbus was a Sephardic Jew, challenging his traditional identity as a Genovese Italian. However, experts question the validity of these claims due to lack of peer-reviewed evidence.

Germany has reintroduced border controls at all its borders, preventing 30,000 people from entering the country. This move is part of a broader trend among EU countries to tighten internal border checks amidst concerns over illegal immigration.

Prabowo Subianto will be inaugurated as Indonesia's president on October 20, following a populist campaign promising economic growth. However, the middle class has declined significantly, raising concerns about economic stability and growth.
London Underground train drivers and other staff are set to strike next month over pay disputes, with significant disruptions expected.
EU leaders struggle to reach consensus on migration and asylum policy ahead of a summit, with various member states proposing different reforms and some opting out of EU laws.
Stora Enso will resume timely payments to suppliers.
Ukraine is the most mine-contaminated country since World War II, impacting global food security and its agricultural economy.

The UK government plans to introduce job coaches in hospitals to assist mental health patients in returning to work, despite concerns from disability rights advocates about potential negative impacts on mental health.

Kylian Mbappé, the captain of the French football team, is linked to a rape inquiry in Sweden, which he calls 'FAKE NEWS'. His lawyer asserts he is calm and has nothing to apologize for, while Swedish authorities investigate the allegations.
Northvolt finalizes savings negotiations affecting 1,600 employees amid financial difficulties.
Central Florida's housing inventory increases for the ninth month, with lower interest rates and a slight decline in home prices.
Kenya's Senate debates the impeachment of Deputy President Rigathi Gachagua following a court ruling that the proceedings are constitutional.
A man has been charged with aggravated animal cruelty for abandoning his dog in floodwaters during Hurricane Milton.

Chancellor Rachel Reeves plans to implement £40bn in tax rises and spending cuts in the upcoming Budget to address a £22bn deficit inherited from the previous government, while aiming to avoid real-terms cuts to public services.

The challenges faced by banks, particularly Nordea, stem from outdated systems and the reliance on aging technology, such as IBM's mainframe and Cobol programming language, leading to difficulties in modernizing and maintaining secure operations.
An extensive investigation into financial crimes related to the Icon real estate group has revealed damages of approximately EUR 9.5 million affecting around 300 investors.
A supermoon is a full moon that occurs when the moon is closest to Earth, appearing larger and brighter than usual.
Private consumption in Finland is increasing, with economists predicting a slight decline in the economy this year but growth in the following years.
HK Foods is selling its Danish business for EUR 44.6 million, ending its operations in Denmark and previously abandoning Sweden.
Boeing seeks $35bn in funding amid ongoing worker strike and layoffs.
A professional shoplifting gang, known as the 'champagne gang', has stolen over £73,000 worth of goods from UK supermarkets using organized tactics and communication technology.

The Nobel Prize in Economics was awarded to Daron Acemoğlu, Simon Johnson, and James A. Ainson for their research on the factors behind national success and failure, emphasizing the importance of democracy, good governance, and societal stability.
The US imposed a $4 million penalty on Lufthansa for discriminating against Jewish passengers on a 2022 flight, where they were barred from a connecting flight due to alleged mask violations.
Jacek Pa.zka announces departure as CEO of Anora.
Hyundai launched its IPO in India, raising $3.3 billion, marking the largest stock market debut in the country.
Metsä Fibre initiates arbitration against Valmet Technologies over financial claims.
UK businesses express concerns over potential National Insurance tax rise for employers, fearing it could hinder job creation and economic growth.

The UK government has confirmed that it will not increase income tax or National Insurance rates ahead of the upcoming Budget, but hints at potential increases in employer National Insurance to address a £22bn deficit.
Hong Kong's property market shows mixed signals with recent rate cuts and rising stock prices, but economic weakness and cautious developer pricing persist.
Expectations for a UK interest rate cut have increased due to slowing wage growth, with analysts predicting a reduction to 4.75% next month despite ongoing inflation concerns.
Climate scientist Tapio Schneider discusses the impact of air pollution reduction on global temperatures and his experiences in climate science.
Google partners with Kairos Power to utilize small nuclear reactors for powering AI data centers.
Burning household rubbish in incinerators is now the dirtiest power generation method in the UK, producing greenhouse gases equivalent to coal power, prompting calls for a ban on new incinerators.
Donald Trump plans to significantly increase tariffs on foreign goods if re-elected, claiming it will protect jobs and boost the US economy, though economists warn that consumers will bear the costs.
NASA's Europa Clipper spacecraft has launched to explore Jupiter's moon Europa for signs of alien life, aiming to arrive by 2030.
Over 160,000 previously unknown RNA viruses have been identified using an AI program called LucaProt, highlighting the vastness of the virosphere on Earth.
U.S. construction input prices fell by 0.9% in September 2024, driven by a decline in oil prices, while some materials saw price increases.
The 2024 Nobel Prize in Economics was awarded to Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, and James A. Robinson for their research on the factors influencing the success and failure of countries.
NASA's Europa Clipper mission aims to explore Jupiter's moon Europa for potential signs of life beneath its icy surface.
NASA is launching a mission to explore Jupiter's Europa moon for signs of liquid water and life.
Study reveals Christopher Columbus was a Western European Sephardian.
SpaceX successfully conducted the fifth flight test of the Starship rocket, achieving successful landings of both the Super Heavy Booster and the Starship.
Tensions escalate between Israel and Iran following missile strikes, with potential implications for global oil prices and regional stability.
Saline solution is in short supply in German hospitals and pharmacies, affecting medical procedures and outpatient care.
Boeing plans to cut 17,000 jobs, 10% of its workforce, due to financial losses from a machinists' strike and production halts.
A geomagnetic storm affecting Finland has been caused by a solar event, with potential for more storms tonight, though cloud cover may hinder visibility.
The comet Tsuchinshan-ATLAS is best viewed on the night between Saturday and Sunday, with optimal viewing conditions expected over the next few weeks.

The 2024 hurricane season has been marked by an unusual pattern of storm formation, with Hurricanes Helene and Milton causing significant damage in the southeastern US after a period of fewer storms despite warm ocean temperatures.
The California Association of Realtors predicts a favorable housing market in 2025 with increased sales and prices due to improved interest rates and inventory.

Klaus Eberhardt's unconventional solution to succession issues in family-owned businesses involves employees collectively buying out his tech firm, iteratec, as many heirs show disinterest in taking over family businesses in Germany.
The Q3 2024 U.S. Foreclosure Market Report shows a decrease in foreclosure filings and starts, with notable declines in several states, while some areas continue to face challenges.
Exercise improves fat tissue quality in overweight individuals, reducing health risks.

The Living Planet report highlights a significant decline in biodiversity, particularly in South America, where wildlife populations have decreased by an average of 95%. The report emphasizes the urgent need for action to address the ongoing natural disasters and climate change affecting ecosystems worldwide.

Hurricane Milton poses a significant risk to residential properties in the Tampa Bay and Sarasota areas, with potential reconstruction costs reaching up to $174 billion depending on the storm's strength at landfall.
Music evokes a wide range of emotions, including joy and sorrow, and its impact on the brain can lead to different reactions in listeners.
Germany's economy is facing a recession with a projected GDP contraction in 2024, compounded by structural issues and global challenges.
The Nobel Prize for Protein Research has been awarded to David Baker, Demis Hassabis, and John M. Jumper for their work on predicting protein structures using AI.

Volkswagen faces significant challenges, including potential plant closures and job cuts due to declining sales and high production costs, amidst a backdrop of rising competition from Chinese EV manufacturers.
Las Vegas real estate prices hit record highs in September 2024, with condos and townhomes reaching an all-time high while single-family home prices nearly matched their peak.
The Nobel Prize winners for Physics and Medicine have been announced, with a focus on machine learning and gene regulation.
Students from Turku, Tampere University, and Åbo Akademi are competing in an international synthetic biology competition in Paris, focusing on food innovation for space travel.

The Sphinx snow patch in Scotland has melted for the fourth year in a row, attributed to climate change, while various other news highlights include job losses in Grangemouth, reflections on the independence referendum, and advancements in rehabilitation technology.
U.S. mortgage applications declined by 1.3% for the week ending September 27, 2024, with a modest increase in mortgage rates.
The German economy faces a prolonged crisis due to stagnant growth and challenges, particularly impacted by a slowdown in China, leading to restructuring and job cuts in major companies.

The Nobel Prize announcements for various categories occur this week, culminating in the Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo. Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun received the Nobel Prize for their research on micro-RNA and gene regulation.
Cooperation between space agencies aims to study asteroids and mitigate potential threats to Earth.
France's new Prime Minister Michel Barnier faces challenges in passing the 2025 budget amid a rising deficit and lack of parliamentary majority.

The U.S. housing turnover rate has reached its lowest point in 30 years, with only 25 out of every 1,000 homes changing ownership in 2024. Factors contributing to this decline include stagnant listings and homeowners locked into low mortgage rates.

World Property Ventures announces a $350 million joint-venture funding round for its subsidiary, World Property Markets, to enhance global real estate search platforms using AI and innovative technologies.
Recent changes to the commission structure in real estate are causing concern among agents, with many predicting negative impacts on the industry and first-time home buyers.
Tensions between Iran and Israel escalate after Iran fires missiles, causing a surge in global oil prices and raising concerns about economic impacts.

The latest ATTOM Data report indicates that home affordability in the U.S. remains low, with 99% of counties analyzed being less affordable than historical averages, despite slight improvements due to declining mortgage rates.
Claudia Sheinbaum begins her term as Mexico's first female president amid economic uncertainty due to Donald Trump's threats to impose tariffs and a controversial judicial reform.
Monaco's housing market faces challenges due to high demand and limited supply, prompting new developments to accommodate the growing population of ultra-high-net-worth individuals.
A new book titled 'Artificial Intelligence Applications Throughout the Real Estate Industry' explores the impact of AI on real estate, covering its evolution, current applications, and future trends.
Housing prices in Ireland rose by 3.1% in Q3 2024, with Dublin experiencing the highest increase at 4.1%. The supply of second-hand homes continues to decline, contributing to rising prices.
Central Europe faces devastating floods exacerbated by climate change, with Storm Boris causing significant damage and loss of life.
Sir David Attenborough reflects on the impact of wildlife broadcasting over his 70-year career, emphasizing its role in raising awareness about conservation issues.

The Titan submersible, designed for deep-sea exploration of the Titanic wreck, tragically imploded during a dive in June 2023, killing all five passengers. A public hearing by the US Coast Guard is set to investigate the design flaws and safety concerns surrounding the vessel.
A massive landslide in Greenland triggered a prolonged seismic event and a mega-tsunami, highlighting the impact of climate change on glacial stability.

The text discusses the advancements and controversies surrounding gene editing in agriculture, particularly in the UK, where new regulations have been paused, raising concerns about animal welfare and international competitiveness.
Sellafield, a major nuclear waste site in the UK, faces challenges in managing radioactive materials and finding a permanent disposal solution.
New legislation in England and Wales aims to combat water pollution by imposing stricter penalties on water company executives, including potential prison sentences and bans on bonuses.
A recent expedition to the Titanic wreck has revealed significant decay, including the loss of a famous railing and the rediscovery of the Diana of Versailles statue.
